archdesc.runner: Special Collections and Archives, James Branch Cabell Library, Virginia Commonwealth University

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections and Archives, James Branch Cabell Library, Virginia Commonwealth University

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Box/folder, Roanoke Valley YWCA records, M 180, Special Collections and Archives, James Branch Cabell Library, Virginia Commonwealth University, Richmond, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of the Board of the YWCA on 20 April 1983

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collection processed in May 1983. Finding aid revised in April 2000.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: The organization began in 1913 after meeting at the Roanoke home of Mrs. A. J. Kennard. The first permanent organization meeting was held in January of 1914 where it met at the Green Memorial Methodist Church. With 1,153 pledge memberships, the E.W. Tinsley property at 415 Roanoke Street was chosen as the first home of the Association. In 1923 the program was extended to African American girls and women with the formation of the Phyllis Wheatley Branch which by the 1950s was called the Lula Williams Memorial Branch. The organization's headquarters began meeting a structure built specifically for the ssociation at the corner of First Street and Franklin Road., S.W. The building was dedicated on May 28, 1928.

As of 2002, the organization was called the YWCA of the Roanoke Valley. Its Executive Director was Pat Reynolds. An indication as to the services and programs it offers can be found in the organization's stated mission which is to "empower women and eliminate racism, the YWCA provides programs in these core areas: residence, child care and youth development, community and leadership development, advocacy and public policy, racial and social justice, targeted special-needs programs, and health and fitness."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The collection includes minutes, reports, newsletters, records of the organizations multiple activities, photographs and clippings. There are a few files involved in the WPA Writers Program.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection has been arranged in six series. Series 1: Board of Directors, 1918-1969; Series 2: Fiscal Records, 1925-1969; Series 3: Executive Director's File, 1901-1951; Series 4: Committees, 1938-1975; Series 5: Photographs and Clippings, 1965-1966, undated; Series 6: Scrapbooks, 1926-circa 1940s.
Materials are arranged in chronological order.

Photographs and oversize materials will be removed to appropriate locations as staff permits. The scrapbooks are housed in their own area and are numbered separately. There is only a rough inventory of the collection.
